A point that I really wish had been mentioned was the problem with car insurance for folks working for these apps. I totaled my car while actively delivering an order and my car insurance refused to cover the lose, would not pay anything at all, because I didn't have the "special" insurance policy they required you to have if you did gig work as an independent contractor. Tips are more like 2/3 of the driver's pay. I'll drive 25-35min and get a $2-$3 fare, so if there's no tip, that equates to ~$6/hr. Not to mention we don't get paid to return to our point of origin. So if the dropoff is out in the boonies it cuts that hourly pay even more as we have to return to civilization. Not to mention gas and wear and tear on our vehicles. Please tip, it really is integral to our overall pay. The other day I was in Boston for 5hrs, got 8 orders. 7 didn't tip. Final pay was about $60. That's just over $10/hr. Minus fuel and the absolute maddening experience of driving around Boston. Please tip. ğŸ‘

One of the biggest problems with us delivery drivers being classified as "independent contractors" is that they actively circumvent the benefits of being an independent contractor.  Like limiting scalability, most do not allow you to have a helper, and you are not able to log in on multiple devices, so you can actually hire employees of your  own. As a contractor there is no legal expectation that you will do the work yourself.  Secondly, as a contractor you are supposed to be able to negotiate your pay for each job you do. With all these delivery apps what you get is "Here is the order, here is the pay. Take it or leave it."

I am really disagreeing with John on this one.  Mainly because it's one of the things that free market can regulate on its own and the intervention from the government will likely not improve it.   I find nothing wrong with the delivery companies wanting to rise the prices up once they cleared the competition field. We've seen it in other industries, it's inevitable. Two-three companies will remain and then there will be an equilibrium between how much the customers can pay and how much the companies can earn. It's the closest to an ideal "fair price" as we can get.  Also whenever the apps start uncontrollably raising prices, this will lead to restaurants providing their own deliveries using the good old phone (and now, using chatbots) and driving the apps out of business.  Of course, in John's ideal world the delivery price is free and the workers deliver it always on sunny days going through beautiful parks and breathing fresh air. But we're not there, and in the real world the equilibrium is reached when everyone is equally dissatisfied.  Also I don't get the appeal to those who are locked home disabled and have "no other choice" than the delivery apps. That argument looks strange because... how did they live before the delivery apps then?  All in all - leave the free market alone. Just ensure there is no monopoly in the end (that would be really bad) and prevent some extreme abuse scenarios (like selling out the data to foreign governments) and we'll be good.

I did about 6 years of pizza delivery in my high school/college years during the early 2000s. I was paid nothing. The delivery service was separate from the pizza place. We charged $1.00 per delivery and 50 cents an item. My boss took 60 cents per delivery and 25 cents an item so he could sit at home while we did all of the work. The maximum number of deliveries I could manage per hour was 12 and it had to be very busy for that. So needless to say, all of the money I made was on tips. And tipping was good and I really did make some really good money especially for a young age.  But tipping is ultimately a scam. I have come to realize that restaurants / delivery services should pay a straight wage, whether it be an hourly rate or per delivery. And this goes for serving, also. Workers need to know how much they're going to make, or at least get an even share of the sales that happen. Tipping does usually average out, but sometimes I lost money making drives to the house I knew never tips due to fuel expenses AND car wear and tear. Don't forget I put labor into that, too. But unlike most workers, I still put in my everything to every delivery because the job had to get done and it did all even out. But the non-tippers would be last if the route efficiently worked against their favor.  There's conflicting information in this video. Restaurants are claiming the delivery services are charging outrageous amounts of money while the delivery services claim they're breaking even at best. I realize they're competing to be the number one service that wins in the long run but they're clearly not losing money on the orders; what must be going on is they're dumping loads of money into advertising, and maybe development but I find it hard to believe that these high valued companies can't afford the development costs with those kinds of margins. So it's not the consumer who is making out; it's the advertising companies.  Back to my own experience, there was a time when my boss was discussing with other restaurants to combine the delivery service so that we could have more consistant rates of deliveries and enough staff to always deliver on time. We were buying the food from the restaurant and then reselling to the customers, basically. So it wouldn't have made a difference who we were delivering for. But my boss was a jerk and the plans for that fell through. It's unfortunate because I think a delivery service like Uber Eats is fantastic. It is much better if people work for a delivery company instead of the restaurant. There's just a lot of issues to work out with how the pricing is figured out. I cannot fathom how these apps would have so much cost to run their system, other than trying to gain more customers through expensive advertising campaigns. Their services should be cheap, the drivers should get paid a reasonable fee per delivery, and nobody should ever have to tip. I do tip very well, but I want our customs to change to where everyone just pays the same for the service so that I'm not paying for some cheap-skate to dine at a restaurant or get delivery to his house. Tipping is not fair; it's bribery.

I rarely use a delivery app, if ever. I will contact restaurants directly and many have their own drivers that deliver food the old fashioned way. Here in Orlando, I might order a meal that would typically cost $30 for two people. If I order through Uber Eats or Door Dash through the app immediately adds 20% to the food prices so the restaurants can make money, and they typically will tack on about $10-$15 for delivery fees, packing fees, etc.  So a meal that would cost $36 delivered directly by the restaurant including tip will cost about $50+ by using an app. Everyone loses in this scenario.
The 'rating' system is flawed, just like it is on Amazon - As a third-party seller, a buyer might be unhappy with a product they buy from you although you may have fulfilled that order perfectly, but buyers will leave a bad rating that will reflect on the seller instead of the product when it was the product that was the problem.

In 2021, the average DoorDash executive was compensated approximately $223, 844. Their CBO made nearly $5 million, the COO made nearly $16 million, and the General Counsel was compensated a cool $10 million. Founder and CEO Tony Xu is worth around $3 billion.  Meanwhile, they pay drivers as little as $2 per delivery without compensation for gas or vehicle upkeep. They are classified as contractors rather than employees so receive no benefits or protection in case of a crash. Not to mention they will owe taxes at the end of the year because that money is not deducted from each paycheck. They are entirely at the mercy of tips, and as a veteran dasher I will confirm that plenty of people are willing to type "0" into the tip box. It isn't a living wage after expenses. It is an exploitative business model that uses people and then hangs them out to dry once their car stops running - which doesn't take long, because one can easily average less than $1 per mile. After gas, maintenance, and taxes, the compensation is even worse than most minimum wage jobs.  Companies like Uber and DD need to be regulated. Don't work for them if you can possibly avoid it.

I kind of challenge the notion that we're getting more under these services as consumers. Maybe the math checks out in major metropolitan areas like new york where costs are higher, but once you factor the inflation on the menu prices, the fees, and the subscription services to lower the fees, you're still paying far more than the marquee price of the food in the restaurant + delivery fee. In a less expensive state, a pizza from a major chain like pizzahut is $15, but plus tax and $5 for delivery. But on doordash, it's $18+, you're still paying 4 dollars for delivery + taxes, range fees, etc. Or you spend $10 a month in order to save 50-100% off the delivery fee. The math only making sense if by paying that $10 per month, you're effectively pledging "Yes, I do wish to die like Elvis on a toilet."

I have done this gig work when I'm between jobs. I worked a lot for Walmart Spark, who kind of contract gig workers more. I had excellent metrics. Then one day they deactivated me. A clear reason was not given. So I couldn't defend myself. I am a 67 year old female, single person and was left with no money at all.   I did manage to get a job as a cashier at Walmart and now finish at midnight every night, so now I have a small income but I have no social life either. Vis a vis the tipping culture in the USA. First of all, it looks like you Mr Oliver have been sucked into the same scam as the general populace where employers are telling customers that the customer is directly responsible for the employees wages. In addition, I have seen a few stories where the employer is taking a cut of the tip.  As for delivery people, don't tip on the app, tip the delivery guy that appears at your door. If I tip, it is always cash, even if the bill is paid by some other means.
So it is different in Australia.  Delivery app's result in a higher charge for food, 10 - 15% mark up. Then, because you can only pay online, cash is not an option but the admin fee for use of a debit/credit card is. There is then an Admin fee for taking the order and a delivery fee for actual delivery. So you can expect an online order to be up to 40% higher than if you ring an order through and pick the product up yourself.  Further, that cost can be 140% higher given all of those fees but after the order is confirmed they don't deliver and charge your account 3 days later so you don't pick it up until your next statement of account from your banking app. Thanks for that DOOR DASH. By the way they refused to credit my card, told me they had credited my account, and refused to cite the name on it when I pointed out I don't have an account with them.  So now, it's a phone order to the establishment and drive round to pick up. Anyone who does not take a direct call has been cut off our list because there are those that do.

As both a former gig worker and current customer of grubhub, I was glad to have some form of income pre-pandemic when I lost my job due to discrimination by my former employer (who I legally can't specify). But the only reason I had to get a gig job despite having a degree and experience, is that I am disabled. I kept at it well into 2020, several months into my new job as a temp office worker. The apps and how people talk online pits customers against drivers in an us vs them fight. No, your drivers are not just eating your food and laughing. We've been sent to a fake restaurant, the wrong address, or you made the order and then fell asleep, or someone else stole your food.    I hope things are a little better for drivers now. Unfortunately, I have to rely on delivery for my groceries even more now, and it's one more reason I'm shamed for being disabled.   I feel that "single slice of cake" part hard, as I once had a delivery to make that was a single slice of pie. I was about ready to go home for the night and even though there was no tip, I accepted it, because I had to accept at least 85% of deliveries. If I went below that ratio, if say i passed on a huge order I couldn't physically fit in my tiny car, or another legit reason, I was removed from signing up for time blocks for the entire next week. If you don't sign up for a block, the only orders you got were ones rejected by literally all other drivers. So I go get the slice of pie from Baker's Square and I get to the address and get a text that I should have been more scared by "come in, the door is unlocked". Frankly, if I wasn't super depressed at the time and basically didn't care that I might have been walking into my own death, I would have left the pie at the outside front door and ran. I got lucky - it wasn't someone luring people to hurt them (which has happened to drivers) but someone who had recently become unable to walk and lived on the 3rd floor. She practically cried in relief because she kept seeing her order get cancelled and all she wanted was something to feel a little better after a very long day.  I never think the people ordering delivery are 'lazy'. That said, I wouldn't do it again. My health was permanently worsened, and I racked up a lot of costs from damage to my car. I barely made rent, despite doing my best to optimize everything and showing the utmost care by having my own cup holders and a cooler and heating pad in an insulated bag in the winter (couldn't afford to run the heat in my car, even below zero). I even chatted with people on reddit because I kept getting no orders and found out I had to commute to the busy parts of the city (which you can't claim on your taxes) and work there, then commute home (also not claimable - only from the restaurant to the customer). The taxes were annoying as hell due to the level of detail required to not get stomped on by the IRS, and I only avoided an audit by using qb self-employed, which was expensive.

I'm normally fine with this show's takes, but there are some things wrong in this one.  1. Tipping should never, ever be mandatory or made to be felt like it should be. Pay proper wages, period. Or if the math does not work out for you as a delivery driver when it comes to base wages without tips, please do something else more economically viable for yourself or petition your local congressman to get establishments to pay proper wages.  2. I shouldn't be forced to rate someone 4 to 5 stars for a botched delivery. Late deliveries are fine, traffic happens, but when the food has been haphazardly loaded into the bag and now the carton is broken and food is spilling all over, best believe I will have my say there since I am paying not just for the food, but also the delivery service.  3. Making it look like buying your own equipment is bad is definitely a red herring. I used to do freelance work, and I never expected all clients who hire me to keep providing me with equipment I need to do the job. That's just part of the upfront costs of being self-employed.  4. Gig work is optional. All due respect and mad props to the guy who kept doing deliveries with a broken foot, but it's highly disingenuous and manipulative to position him as being forced by delivery apps to keep working. He was not, he chose to keep working with a bum foot. He has always had agency as a gig worker, but the show tries to make it seem like he doesn't. There's also the implied, but not proven, idea that app algorithms include time off in deciding if a gig worker should be booted or not. It was never proven to be as such, but the heavy lean by the writing to seem like medical time-off does factor in is highly suspect, and again, disingenuous.  There seems to be a huge misunderstanding by this show's writers what gig work is. It's not supposed to be a regular day job - at best, it's something one should be doing as a side hustle. If you have the gumption to string together multiple gigs (in this case, deliveries) and make enough money to make it your day job, more power to you, but it doesn't mean that doing app-based deliveries IS a day job and should be treated as such complete with the usual expectations we have for what day jobs are and should have. It's temp work, that's it.

Tipping ONLY your table's server, especially in a restaurant, is so messed up.   Did your server prep your foods? Did they take the time to make sure the food was all cooked perfectly? Most likely, No! A restaurant runs something like a Team. There is no "I" in Team!  From the time you or you are seated, the server has a few key-things to do: take your order, bring drinks, make sure everything is great, bring the bill, & clean the table afterwards.  What about the entire kitchen staff [prep-workers, chef(s), washers, etc.]?  Everyone working that particular shift should receive an even portion of the "gross tips." Always! But in many cases don't.   The point of "Tip Culture" in promoting owners to pay less in wages in many States or Provinces with minimum wage laws enforced, is not entirely based on facts.  If the owner is cheap, they will run their business/restaurant that way, & vice versa. One of the main culprits of paying just the minimum/liveable wage at restaurants is how much of a steady increase the "wholesale produce/products" costs are. In many cases, this percentage far exceeds the inflationary rate.  Lastly, "Guilt Tipping" & or "Gratuity Fees," especially at places where no one has really gone out of their way to assist your entire dining or service experience, is sad to say the least.

As a former delivery driver for Uber Eats I can attest to this. I would regularly get tipped extremely little or not at all for deliveries. People have stopped using fast food and tipping due to costs.
This is a seriously charged issue for several reason, but as a former chef for over 15 years, yall need to undestand one VERY important part...  Tipping culture only benefits managers and ownership.  On average, restaurant PROFITS are anywhere from 2-9%. That's considering 1/3 for food cost, 1/3 for front/back of house labour and around 20% static costs such as rent, utilities, etc.  House tips, which servers overcontribute to, end of subsidizing kitchen wages. While, problematicly, being distributed to 'managers' discretion.   However, the ideology of tipping culture is now truly overextended. Services like Hvac installation now include a tip option. Not only does 70% of your income come from tips, so if people donâ€™t you literally make almost nothing, In order to even have a CHANCE of making minimum wage you cannot stop even for a second during your work day, no lunch, no drinks, no phone calls nothing as you get no stipend for being clocked in whatsoever, you only get money for making deliveries themselves. You need to be 100% focused driving and delivery orders as fast as you can. Not to mention gas will literally eat over half of your money just by itself. Traffic jams, long elevators, people slow to answer doors, all cost you and you are, like I said, *painfully* aware of that fact. Every single one is infuriating as you are literally watching your money tick away with time. And we havent even gotten to the worst part. When you are offered a job you have TEN SECONDS to decide whether to accept it, and sometimes, you will literally end up with a job that costs more in gas to deliver than you actually make from the delivery itself and thatâ€™s assuming you get a GOOD TIP. If you get a bad tip youâ€™ll literally lose money. Most people donâ€™t order large amounts of food so the tips are tiny even if they are large % wise. You can literally get assigned a job where it will take 40 minutes to pick up and deliver the food and youâ€™ll make 5$ TOTAL. 40 minutes for 5$ and remember it probably cost more than 5$ in gas. You have no idea how much you will make for a drive in advance as the only number the app gives you is the â€œpotential earningsâ€ which includes what Uber pays you PLUS what they think you *should* get in tips. I'm a former Instacart shopper and I agree with the experts that this is not a remotely profitable business model, ever, even when they get to the jacking up prices stage. I actually think Instacart/grocery delivery has the best shot. Shopping for a grocery order does take longer than picking up takeout (and be aware that the person who delivers your Instacart order is the same person who shopped for it in the store in the vast majority of cases), but it also costs a lot more, meaning a percentage-based tip is much higher, and the customer will accept a higher delivery price. (I quit Instacart after they cut pay by about 50%, by the way.)   But consider traditional restaurant delivery: there's a reason we only ever saw it from a few types of restaurants who paid a delivery staff before. Most food does not travel well. Most food does not keep well, meaning both that it's hard to reheat leftovers and that after half an hour the quality has dropped significantly. Most menu items are one serving, meaning that whatever you're paying for delivery, you're getting a single meal out of it rather than multiple. Before apps, you pretty much saw delivery only with Asian foods (inclusive of both Chinese and Indian) and pizza. These foods are packed in boxes by default, so they can knock around a bag a little bit and be fine (slightly less true with pizza, which is why pizza delivery developed specialized bags for it). These foods don't suffer in quality in half an hour, and they're exceptionally easy to reheat in a microwave. A medium pizza can comfortably feed four people lunch, or one person dinner for a few days, and the same is generally true of a few dishes off a Chinese or Indian menu. But now, these apps expect to deliver an $8 cake slice, charge $7 for the delivery, pay the driver $2, and hope the customer will tip enough for a SINGLE SERVING OF DESSERT to bring that up to a fair wage for the driver's half hour of work.  The model is utterly insane, and has only lasted as long as it has because the companies have a nigh-endless supply of desperate people willing to work delivery because they can't find or sustain another job (an underestimated factor is that a lot of delivery gig workers are disabled and choose gig work because it allows them to work when they feel able, sit down most of the time, and not have to answer for when they're not working). In other words, it only works because they can suck the blood out of an underclass. This is the type of shit you find in YA dystopia novels, and no one even realizes they're the Capitol in this one.  P.S. Instacart was even an option for me because I live in Canada and don't need health benefits, but it's worth considering that hauling multiple 24- or 40-packs of bottled water to fourth-floor walkup apartments significantly worsened my existing carpal tunnel. It was relatively minor before delivery work and now my hands tingle and my wrists hurt all the time when the cortisone wears off. In Canada, I can go to the doctor and get an ultrasound and get cortisone shots without an issue, but if I'd had to do this in the US I'd be fucked now, because Instacart would NOT be paying me enough to pay rent and also pay thousands in medical bills. This is a two-income household btw. My advice if you're going to try gig delivery: do Amazon Flex. They've got an infrastructure in place and while the challenges are unique from other apps, they pay enough (especially on short-notice surge blocks) that you can at least cover your expenses and have something left. Also, get a trip-tracking app on your phone so you can take mileage off your taxes. It's worth paying a subscription fee if you can't find a free one, it brought my income down by nearly $8000 in the 7 months of last year I was delivering. Calculating the tax deduction by standard mileage rate is almost always going to get you a bigger deduction than tracking your actual expenses, and it's way easier. My actual expenses per kilometer are probably around 25 cents, while the CRA rate last year was 62.5 cents/km for the first 5000 km and 55 after that.

It's more than just tipping culture, though that doesn't help. I used to run a non profit transportation company, and transport as a business is a lot more expensive than we realize. When I drove for Uber, it was easy to put 200-300 miles on my car per day. That is an oil change every month, not to mention all the other maintenance, which you can't skip because your car is essential to your income. So that means you need at least $30/hr to make an actual living, and the algorithms try to incentivize a larger fleet rather than a focused one. So the more you drive, the less frequently you get trips, which means you are available but not getting paid, and your average wage goes down. I do think there could be a path forward to profitability, but not with a goal of infinite growth stonks always go up. It will require a workforce of professional drivers who aren't subsidizing app companies with their vehicles, and higher prices than we might expect.

I worked for a company that is owned by the same parent as GrubHub, in Canada. They're called Skip the Dishes, and were legitimately one of the first of these kinds of apps.   Anyway, I started working for one in December 2018. When I first started, I had a pretty easy time. When I needed to contact someone at Skip, I could, my orders were valuable, the broker (Skip) wasn't taking a huge cut, and the restaurants were all pretty happy.  I stuck with them for a while because I actually did enjoy driving and being able to set my own schedule. I was making a living wage.   Then the pandemic hit. And at first it was great, until the rest of the world realized that this was a lucrative business and sign-ups for courier jobs went absolutely insane. This was already fairly normal around holiday seasons (people trying to buy Christmas stuff, or trying to save money for a summer vacation), but they just never stopped bringing more drivers in.   By the time I quit in 2023, my time spent working had nearly doubled while my wages were less than a quarter what they were when I started. My cut to the company was getting bigger. Customers were getting burnt out on tipping, and these brokers are making it quite clear that the tip is really what's paying the drivers. No one wants to be guilted in to paying someone money because the employer wont. It was fine during the pandemic, we were all in it together and people were super supportive. But that time has passed.  I mentioned that when I started, the broker was very easy to deal with. They had a phone number I could call and reach someone at any time. Then suddenly they introduced a chat feature, which should tell you volumes about the company when they unilaterally decided that the best way for a courier to contact the company was by text message. I mean, that's an absolute farce. But fine, we could still call in. Until the pandemic hit, and suddenly they had FEWER employees and were no longer accepting phone calls, demanding everything be done after your shift. Basically, if you had a problem, they didn't care.  But it just kept getting worse and worse and worse. If I did have concerns about my account, or try to reach a "boss," they'd make me schedule a for days in the future, and god forbid your phone drops a call, because they will NOT call back and you have to start over. I one time needed to get some clarification on my account and it took nearly 2 weeks to speak to someone about it.   You can't even call the company any more, because they literally blocked the agents from having access to the information. It all must be chat (yes I keep saying this) or e-mail (which they quite literally never answer, and is regularly just patrolled by a bot that sends auto-replies based on keywords). Yes, I ABSOLUTELY had an algorithm for a boss.   The scorecard, by the way:  Company decreases pay, increases amount they take per order. Company starts increasing charges to restaurants, taking up to, according to one client, 38% of the gross sale per order. They feel they have no choice but to stay lest they completely go under because basically everywhere is seeing a very significant portion of their revenue from mobile ordering. Restaurants feel like they have no other choice but to be on these networks, often multiple (In Canada it's common to see Uber Eats, DoorDash, and Skip the Dishes terminals at most places).  Company lays people off during pandemic, makes it increasingly harder to get support (from a department called Courier Care, no less).  Company starts demanding customers pay more money. Customers won't pay, company won't pay, driver gets stiffed. Constant influx of more drivers, thinning the already thinning number of orders coming in as the world continues to open back up and "go back to normal."   Then it started getting dystopian. They'd start randomly pulling orders from you. Then they added a "feature" to keep track of us, which basically monitored our GPS for movement. We'd get a warning if we were stopped for too long, and a second warning meant they took the order. When they first added it, it wasn't tested and would trigger as soon as you accepted an order, or would trigger while you were driving (then requiring you to interact with your phone so you didn't lose money, another illegal distraction). If you complained to them about it, they'd tell you it's working perfectly.  Stopping for too long, by the way, also included red lights. 5-6 times a week, I'd be sitting at a red light on my way to get an order, and it'd be taken from me for not moving. Was the intention for me to run the red light too?  They forced an acceptance rate on us, where if we slipped under 80% order acceptance (over the last 10 orders), we'd actively lose money. Ostensibly it was to ensure we made more money, but it was more to deal with the fact that drivers stopped taking orders worth 1-2 dollars that would take 20-30 minutes to deliver. Under 80% meant you made less and were actively de-prioritized for orders.  Final score: I went from making $1200 a week to, if I was lucky, $200-250 a week. This was before gas, which was $75 a week (fuel efficient car and some hypermiling), before expenses, certainly before insurance. If I was lucky, I'd have $40-50 in my pocket for the week. My wife was shouldering the entire burden of the home while I desperately worked as many shifts as I could while trying to find a "real" job. Blow a tire (it happened)? They don't care, they just want to know if the order was delivered.  I was injured at a customers house, the company outright started hanging up on me because they were afraid I was going to file a compensation claim.  I was putting 50,000km on my car a year. That's at least 5 oil changes, all out of pocket.  I was putting at least $3k in maintenance in to my car a year.   End result: I'm broke, making technically negative money, while they post RECORD FUCKING REVENUE BABY  They call us independent contractors, but you have no actual choice in when you can work (they'd give you a schedule with 2-3 shifts on it, then you'd have to wake up at 7am to catch the free-for-all shifts they released every morning), we had no actual agency in what orders we took because of the punishment that came with it. We were legitimately employees in everything but name. The UK has already clarified that couriers are not independent contractors, and honestly, it's time for that to happen everywhere. They actively request that we break the law, by requiring us to look at our phones near constantly, even when driving.  Please, when drivers are bitchy about tips, THESE are the reasons. I know that from the outside looking in, we're just people who drive from place to place dropping off orders. But seriously, if you understood the stress and pressure they put you under just to try and make a living, you'd understand why. Is it the customers fault? Not really. I have never ordered food delivery through an app, nor would I, but I did work for UberEats for a couple years and it is not something I would recommend, nor something I will ever do again. I actually didn't mind getting out to work every single day with no days off, but it took a toll on my car driving the mileage way up a lot faster than normal, oil changes more frequently, filling up the gas tank every other day, insurance, and dealing with the occasional fender bender, all paid for out of my own pocket. Tips were not always the best, but many customers paid with cash, some better than others. I stopped working for UberEats when they implemented the practice to stop showing drivers all the information needed for an order if the driver declined too many orders. There are often orders that either didn't pay out enough to make it worth the drive or went to restaurants or drop-off locations that I wasn't comfortable going to and I would decline them. There were also often times when I'd get an order pop up while driving and it only gives 30 seconds to either accept or decline or you lose the order automatically and that's just not safe to have to look at the app to see the info and decide while driving. I ended up stopping work for UberEats and started working for DoorDash for a couple weeks until I hit another car and totaled mine. I decided then that I didn't feel comfortable driving at all anymore and I haven't driven since.

The restaurant business model is by far the most disgusting one we have in America that outright screws its workers.   People donâ€™t realize that there is about to be some tremendous changes in California due to new fast food minimum wage increase.  Many will leave the restaurant industry and would rather take the potential small temporary loss working at fast food restaurants. Over time it will be a gain since I forsee many restaurants closing because of low staff and you will see businesses with existing bakeries (exempt to new $20/hour minimim wage increase) open up franchises since they will be able to hire low wage workers to run those joints and will make hand-over-fist with that revenue stream.
I previously worked in HR at a food delivery company. Part of my job was to manage workers' compensation claims when delivery workers were injured on the job. This happened frequently because they would be biking through NYC in congested traffic, at the mercy of reckless drivers and pedestrians who didn't have the common sense to not stand in the middle of bike lanes. Too many times, they would get hit by a taxi driver who cut them off to make a right turn or slam right into a car door because a careless passenger didn't look behind them first to see if it was safe to exit their vehicle. These accidents incapacitated workers for days, weeks, even months, during which they accumulated numerous medical bills and endured the stress of not knowing when they could return to work to support themselves and their families. Filing a claim with the state was not an efficient process, and the compensation the state would offer them would be nowhere close to what they had been earning on the job.   These delivery workers literally risk their lives just to make life more convenient for those with privilege and money. I think if more people were aware of this, we would think twice before ordering food on an app just because we would rather not call the restaurant to place an order and drive a mile to pick up the order ourselves.  What is most disturbing, however, is how we as a society have gotten to a point where it is too convenient to buy convenience. We can pay more money for same-day delivery for items that we don't absolutely need that week, and we can pay more money for someone else to do our grocery shopping so we never have to leave our house to ensure our basic survival needs are met. Unfortunately, such practices prey on the most vulnerable members of our communities and put merchants in a terrible bind, and we as consumers also suffer when we give up small behaviors like browsing our neighborhood stores and interacting with cashiers and waitstaff. There is no humanity left in the consumer experience; it is all transactional.    I was eventually laid off from my former company. Since then, I've boycotted all delivery apps. It's been well over a year since I've had any food delivered, and I'm doing just fine. I never needed my meals delivered to my door; I was just manipulated to depend on these apps and to believe that this was a valuable service that made my life better, when it really didn't.

This entire episode has further deepened my depression in an inexplicable way. Due to health reasons, I was forced to abandon my 20 year career and work through these apps. In many ways (as explained here), these services are borderline unethical. Money isn't actually a problem in my area. I make 90% of what I did as a journeyman machinist while working around 70% of the hours. One of the key things that is lacking from this commentary is the ability to make your business, not you, the private contractor. It is beyond possible to setup employer insurance, PTO, and most of the usual benefits while contracting for these apps. Even transforming that dreaded 1099 into a W-2. The biggest issue, in my opinion, is the marketing that working like this is solely for an individual and not a business. I setup my business account to take a direct percentage, and I pay myself with a regular weekly check. The largest flaw for the workers isn't the pay, it is scumbag corporate marketing deciding that you can do this for "a few extra bucks" and refusing to elaborate on the necessary business savvy to make it actually work full time.   Also, this piece didn't touch on the biggest issue outside of major cities - getting shifts. DoorDash is especially bad at actually offering the "you choose when to work" gimmick when you aren't in a city that can support constant 24/7 shifts. In suburbia, you are lucky to get a shift that isn't 12-4 am because they will let literally anyone with a license do it. As far as just in general being able to work, GrubHub is the most flexible. If orders pop up, you can take them. In my area, InstaCart is the absolute worst because I live juuussttttt close enough to the mountains in north GA, that I'll frequently get offered $30 to drive about 60 miles total into the mountains after I've done the actual shopping.  I guess  my point is that overall, the biggest bruise that these apps cause is the idea that an individual with no business sense whatsoever can... run a business. By themselves. With no support. I'm aware that everything that I've said is anecdotal, but please take it to heart.

These jobs absolutely do not meet the requirements for independent contract workers.  Independent contractors are businesses that negotiate payments for each job, can subcontract work out if they want, dictate how they do a job, and tell their clients what's possible and what's not.  These delivery companies clearly are hiring employees, not clients signing contracts with businesses.    No one should be working for the companies until they change their policies to be legal.

A couple big issues things John failed to cover:  The notion of a tip is subterfuge. It's an intentional misnomer. It's not a tip, it's a bid for service. They want more people ordering so they call it a tip so people think it's extra, it's not. Low and no tip orders are essentially like booking a plumber to fix your sink at their own expense. People also have it in their head that since it's a tip that they should base it off their order total, like they are in a restaurant, rather than basing it off mileage, weather, or that they live at the top floor of a maze-like apartment complex. These delivery drivers pay all their own expenses, gas, vehicle maintenance, and licensing and registration fees, etc. So in many cases due to the expense require to operate, drivers are actually loosing money on these low and no tip orders.  Then when people think they are generously tipping 25% on their $20 order, they fail to take into account the driver had to travel 20 miles round trip and that "generous" 25% tip didn't even cover the gas.   Additionally, the algorithm and driver metrics systematically exploit people. On doordash for example you have a metric called Acceptance Rating. The percentage of offers you accept or decline. They have certain tiers and drivers with lower acceptance ratings are less likely to get higher paying orders. So they are psychologically abusing people into taking low and no tip orders to keep their AR up so they can continue to supposedly get the better offers. But you can't get better offers if you're currently on an order so it makes no sense.  It's quite frankly disgustingly dystopian.

Think of a tip as an offer for service, not a favor.  Understand that, when driver gets several orders in a row, the gig app doesn't pay them for each. They pay the while time/mileage for each order, only for the distance from one drop to the next. For each of the additional orders, the tip essentially becomes they only pay they get for that order.  For the love of physics, don't order prepared frozen confections (cups/cones/cakes from Coldstone, Marble Slab, Baskin Robbins etc.) for delivery through apps. As the journalist says at [21:43], the delivery apps seem too good to be true because they aren't charging what the service really costs. And as much of the segment points out, this is because the model is broken by design, abusing both workers and even restaurants. While I certainly empathize with the delivery workers deserving fair compensation, the right way to go about this is not to rely on tips. That allows the delivery apps to continue neglecting a key component of the business model (ie. labor costs) while putting that load on the customers in a non-transparent way.  It would seem like we have the technology to figure this out. Navigation software can typically give a decent estimate for travel time. That can be multiplied by the desired target wage with adjustments for other conditions (eg. weather, unusually large orders, etc.) and profit. So in the case of that single slice of cake delivery, if the bike route for that was 45 minutes and the delivery worker was to be paid $20/hr, then the delivery fee could be $15 ($20/hr x 0.75 hrs). The customer knows up front that they are going to pay for that slice of cake, and the delivery worker gets paid what they worked out with their employer.

I haven't gotten the feeling that the customer is winning in this exchange. In addition to the food costing more (if the delivery companies aren't making a profit, they need to axe their executives (preferably literally)), there's now zero accountability for bad service.  I've been on all sides of this exchange, as a delivery app worker, a restaurant employee, and a food orderer. If the wrong food gets delivered, the food is wholly or partially missing, or the food is cold/takes forever to arrive, the restaurant will blame the delivery person and the delivery company will blame the restaurant or just shrug and say better luck next time. I didn't deliver for long enough to see how getting poor reviews would affect my ability to get orders, but based on my more experiences working in a restaurant and ordering food, there will always be more bad delivery drivers to take the place of any that stop working due to bad reviews.  The only solution I see is for local restaurants to go back to hiring their own delivery drivers (and they won't need 15 either unless they're delivering thousands of orders every hour). To do this they will have to get over the idea that their employees have to be working at 100% capacity 100% of the time. Skeleton crews increase mistakes, cause burnout, cause worse service, and force employees to work sick. It's a cutthroat market and labor is expensive, but so is throwing money at an objectively worse option via delivery apps.

I gotta be real, I'm not fully informed on all the caveats, but we need to address the 'independent contractor' loophole that so many companies abuse in the US. If the person doesn't need to create an LLC or register a business to do the work, you are employing them, full or part-time, and they NEED to be legally entitled to some manner of employee protection. In some states independent contractors get taxed like they're business owners, too, which further cuts into the absolute shit pay and is completely moronic. These models rely on the exploitation of the most vulnerable people, and our government hasn't shown an interest (save for places like New York and California) in actually addressing these issues.

WASHINGTON DC-AREA RESIDENTS with a hankering for lion meat lost a valuable source of the (yes, legal) delicacy last year when a restaurant called the Serbian Crown closed its doors after nearly 40 years in the same location. The northern Virginia eatery served French and Russian cuisine in a richly appointed dining room thick with old world charm. It was best known for its selection of exotic meats -- one of the few places in the US where an adventurous diner could order up a plate of horse or kangaroo. "We used to have bear, but bear meat was abolished," says proprietor Rene Bertagna. "You cannot import any more bear."  But these days, Bertagna isn't serving so much as a whisker. It began in early 2012, when he experienced a sudden 75 percent drop off in customers on the weekend, the time he normally did most of his business. The slump continued for months, for no apparent reason. Bertagna's profits plummeted, he was forced to lay off some of his staff, and he struggled to understand what was happening.  Only later did Bertagna come to suspect that he was the victim of a gaping vulnerability that made his Google listings open to manipulation.
If anyone doesn't fully comprehend how malicious it is to list a restaurant as closed, just look up "Serbian Crown closed down because of fraudulent Google maps information.". Someone changed the listing for a restaurant that had been open for almost 40 years to say that it was closed or closed on weekends.  By the time the family that owned the restaurant figured out why business had dropped off by 80%, they had gone bankrupt and shuttered the restaurant.  They had to fire fifty or sixty people.

I'm all for these workers getting treated fairly, but the gig-worker laws meant to help them hurt every other kind of freelancer. I'm a technician in entertainment production and we tend to start as full-time employees for corporations with the dream of someday going freelance. Freelancers make better money, get to be their own boss, continue doing the work they love without having to take promotions into management just to make a decent income, choose what jobs they take, and take time off when they need or want it. I've made way more money and lived a much better life as a freelancer than the jobs I had building up to it. But these freelancer laws have made it harder for companies to hire us and are ruining the dream. There has to be a distinction between gig workers and professionals who are freelance by choice.

1. The purpose of any for-profit business is to make as much money as possible, they will always try to minimize costs. There's no such thing as "fair", the prices and wages are (or should be) determined by the laws of supply and demand. 2. The rating system helps to filter out people who don't do their job well. Rating everyone 5 stars would disincentivize workers to adhere to certain standards or even incentivize criminal behavior. At least 20% of them doesn't deserve five stars. The same is true for tipping. 3. Introducing a minimum wage --> increase in prices for consumers --> the demand for food delivery orders goes down --> less revenue for restaurants; fewer delivery people and restaurant workers employed. Pretty much everyone loses, other than the delivery people who keep their jobs.

As a former server, let me help break down tipping culture very simply. In a perfect world, exceptional tips are for exceptional service, good tips are for good service, and bad tips are for bad service. The problem with tipping begins when good or exceptional service goes unrewarded. If you want to tip a bad server, you either have a lot of mercy, a lot of money to waste, or both, but good servers are the people who deserve those tips. As a waiter, I would understand a low tip if I did a poor job, but getting a low tip on a high dollar bill that I attentively served through the whole meal, that is cruel.

I appreciate LWT covering this topic because it's rather absurd how these companies operate. However, I feel like there were a number of misses in the discussion.   For instance, the onus of 5-star reviews shouldn't be on the consumer - that's a problem with the companies. Instead of telling the consumer that they should always leave a 5-star review for their food instead push for the companies to default the review to the food and then give a separate option to review the delivery.  The same goes with tipping. Why is it the consumer's fault that the workers aren't being paid appropriately? I get that it's still the culture and we should participate until its changed, but that person with the slice of cake was merely using a service made available to them. They had no way of knowing that the person delivering the food would be on a bike or that it would be their only order on the trip. Offloading the issue onto tips merely artificially lowers the cost of the product.  I also really wish they'd focused more on how disruptive these services are to the restaurants. Like when the apps offer a free item during a specific day and time which leads to the restaurant having to basically shut down due to too many orders, especially considering the restaurant workers themselves often don't even know about the promotion. Or how consumers are regularly blaming the restaurants for being incorrectly listed on the app.

As someone who drives for DoorDash as my primary means of income, tips aren't 1/3-1/2 of my income, they're well over half, easily 60% or more of my income is from tips. When you order delivery and don't tip, you're directly hurting the driver.  In my state the cost of vehicle operation/mile is around 50 cents, that being the number used when doing taxes to include gas, wear on the vehicle, insurance, etc. I've taken deliveries where the cost of delivering was more than I was paid, and before you try to tell me to just not take those orders, I have to keep my acceptance rate up to keep my job. The app doesn't stop you from dashing if you have a low acceptance rate, but it puts you at last priority on the schedule, meaning you have to fight for shifts and/or pray it's busy enough when you want to work, instead of being able to actually dash whenever and wherever like I can with high acceptance rate. I will literally spend slow days taking basically every offer I get, even at a loss, to boost acceptance so that I can afford to decline bad offers at busy times like Friday nights when I need to maximize earnings.

I read Uber's most recent "investor update." It's all hype and very little substance. Here's some key takeaways from this EIGHTY-TWO SLIDE PRESENTATION; In FY 2023 they had 138 BILLION in gross bookings, total money transferred from consumer to company. And they crow about how amazing their 4 billion EBITDA is -- oh, wait, EBITDA is a pretty meaningless number used just to pump numbers up. The "EB" stands for "Earnings Before" and "ITDA" stands for all those pesky things that companies don't want to acknowledge: Interest, Taxes, Depreciation, and Amortization.   Here's the thing, if you take out a ten million dollar loan, use it to make eleven million dollars, and owe two million dollars between interest and taxes, good news you've just lost a million dollars, but EBITDA gets to show a million dollar "income!"  Anyway, Uber's GAAP (Generally Accepted Accounting Principles) show only 1.11 billion in FY 2023, their first profitable year on record. If you look at the statement from Grubhub, the restaurant paid 3550 for promotions, aside from which Grubhub only (sorry, "only") took 36%. Let's assume, for argument's sake, that that restaurant paid for more promotions than they ought to have, and add 2250 for promotions to make it a 50/50 cut.   But let's do some quick, back-of-the-envelope maths here. If Grubhub and Uber take similar commission percents, we can figure that roughly 69 (nice) billion dollars went to the various businesses and 69 (nice) went to Uber. Somehow, Uber managed to take 69 (nice, ok I'll stop) billion dollars and turn it into... uh... one billion.   That's hilariously inefficient. They're spending 68 billion dollars on things OTHER than the actual literal product and service. Literally, where is that money going? A lot's going to executives (CEO makes 24 million/year), and if I'm reading this financial report correctly they bought 8 billion dollars of marketable securities (stock buybacks) and spent 2 billion dollars on stock-based compensation. Translation: The company is making shitloads of money, actually. they're very profitable, but of course in a way that only benefits a tiny percentage of people.   Their median pay for their employees (NOT DRIVERS, who are independent contractors) is about $70,000/yr. That's respectable, that's fine. But those median-paid employees aren't getting rich, they aren't the ones sucking ten billion dollars out of a company.   The way to make money in America is to have money.

I was actually a bit let down by this episode. No one deserves to be underpaid for their work. However, services like DoorDash employ a tactic where they factor in tips to reduce the hourly wage. Although it's accurate that 100% of tips go directly to the delivery workers (which they advertise proudly and frequently), what isn't disclosed is the adjustment of mileage/hourly rates based on the tip amount to align with their perceived appropriate total compensation. This adjustment is made for each delivery trip, effectively allowing companies to use tips as leverage. By ignoring this detail, asking people to tip more inadvertently aids these corporations in exploiting both consumers and delivery personnel further. What needs to be done is more pressure on these companies to increase the minimum wage.

So, I had started a Food Delivery Service before the rest, after graduating into the Great Recession in 2007, with student loans and no job offers. I did it with $3,000 to my name and no access to debt. Half the restaurants in my area went out of business in that recession but some of the restaurants I worked with told me I saved their business. I had co-graduates applying for delivery jobs, it was that type of economy. They made double minimum wage... more than I was earning. I charged less and didn't increase prices either. In the end, after 5 years running, living on takeout, I had some severe health problems. I had to get out early, and the industry changed after... but I can tell you that when a restaurant owner pays 60% to the delivery services it is because they decided to run a ton of marketing when first signing up and had cancelations or complaints. Advertising is always a long game and delivery apps are advertisers much like the Yellow Pages once were. I was literally competing with Yellow Pages in 2007 because most people still called in their takeout order over the phone. I don't know if I would have survived that market, I knew some really awful restaurant delivery owners in the industry. I'm glad I'm not still doing that.
I am glad that I have never, not once, have had any of these apps (Uber and Lyft included), and have never had anyone else order for me, nor will I ever. I take regular cabs and go out to pick up my food. I do not even order pizza delivery. Try it sometimes.

Another app we use, DiDi Food, has the way of letting reviews to have an effect on the algorithm, with the biggest downside being that there's no standards on any reviews. Which sounds fine since it's just customer reviews, but when a valid criticism is that the "portion was small", and they order something that's literally called "Small Sized Order...", you begin to realize that you're essentially being punished by dumb customers.   And depending on the circumstances, you HAVE to use more than one app, because given the rise of this market, sometimes it really is a matter of seeing which one sticks. Before these two apps, i went with Uber Eats, which was the only one available in my city, but as time went on, DiDi Food became the main app for service, drying out UberEats, and after that, Rappi had a wave of success and eventually became the 2nd tier app.

I rarely comment on youtube videos, but this video is so important right now. This is such a complex issue with elements John didn't even touch on, that ultimately ends up just destroying the little guys. As a food service worker of nearly a decade, I have witnessed firsthand the way that the restaurant industry has been turned completely on its head by food delivery apps. It's not just because I'm from Chicago that I make reference to The Bear, but the episode wherein which they set themselves up for remote orders and get their shit Absolutely Rocked is all too real.   It's all but impossible at this point in the cycle to NOT be a part of delivery apps even if they do basically threaten to bust your kneecaps if you don't give them half of your revenue. For a lot of restaurants, that 50% revenue if 50% they wouldn't be getting because people simply can't or won't go to the stores themselves. I know this personally as someone who doesn't drive (because on top of not being able to afford a house, I can't afford a car either lmao); the last thing I want to do after being on my feet for 10 hours at a restaurant is to walk and stand inside of another restaurant to pick up my dinner! But regardless of how much the restaurant's need the service that these apps provide, as John mentioned, a lot of places aren't set up for delivery- and not just local businesses! I work for a nationwide chain and I have worked through multiple COMPLETE remodels of locations JUST so that they can be better suited for the culture shift into delivery dining. I'm talking entire portions of back and front of house layouts carved out in order to create a more intuitive setup for preparing and handing off delivery orders.   And just like in the episode of The Bear I referenced, even though restaurants no longer have to have delivery staff themselves to meet the market demands, the fact that someone can place an order without knowing twenty other people have placed an order at the same time or knowing that their delivery drivers are all fighting under the same time constraints, has DRASTICALLY changed the way restaurant staff are able to handle the process of preparing and serving food. And again it's just to make the same revenue we would've had five years ago, so we can't justify changing the staffing of the store we just have to change the expectations of what that staff has to do.   To reiterate, there are still things that John didn't touch on, which is that unlike the constant ads you probably get to sign up for these gig work platforms, it's not all part-time college-age white kids looking for extra cash! From what you may have picked up on from the interviews with delivery driver's themselves, all you need most times to work for these companies is a valid driver's license and insurance; which is to say the amount of gig work is done, especially in major cities, by immigrants. Which on top of perpetuating the exploitation of immigrant labor, it makes the rating system all the more insidious because when the majority of the clientele restaurant workers are communicating with don't speak English/Spanish or a language someone in the restaurant can speak, things tend to slip through the cracks! If a customer receives only half of their order because of a communication barrier with the driver, that most likely directly results in a bad review for the delivery driver, not to mention the refund although processed through the third-party app IS REFLECTED in the revenue the restaurant receives and reflects poorly on OUR service which means we may lose further business because we can't guarantee every delivery driver is on the same page as the restaurant staff (which we could do if they WERE our staff).   So tl;dr As both a consumer and provider of this service I say this: Customers deserve the food and service they pay for and food service/delivery workers deserve the profits they work for WITHIN THE CONFINES OF HUMANE LABOR.
I am grateful for "Last Week Tonight" for bringing this sad situation to the attention of the public.

So this is close to my heart since I'm a consumer. I doubt that John will ever see this post but food delivery is the bottom rung of this issue. The higher rungs are:  1. For cab drivers, this varies by city. However in big cities this gets a bit crazy. The classic example is NYC where you need medallions to drive a yellow cab in Manhattan. Before Uber/Lyft e.g. these went for 1M+. Most are owned by large companies since the only way it's worth that much is if the cab is going 24/7. So what happens is that the medallions are rented out in shifts to drivers for a fixed cost (e.g. 600/wk for an 8 hr shift per day). All the risk is on the driver. There's an HBS case about this wherein a medallion as an ETF would fetch ~80k per year  for the owner and ~20k per year for drivers. It basically traded as an 8% bond for traders. Ride sharing initially offered  shared risk models where it was~75-25 rev split between the driver and platform. That was great because it helped drivers, helped consumers and the value of the medallions fell by almost 50%.  2. That split has shifted. Uber has flipped it from what drivers tell me to 30-70. It's messed up. The drivers still get the full tip but I do the mental math of the cost of my ride and sometimes the cost of depreciation to the vehicle, gas etc also is less than the cost of the ride without even including the cost of the time to the driver  These issues need to be addressed. I know JO doesn't beat down on left leaning issues but things like medallions are examples of economic rent seeking for parasites and this rev split is the other side. Make the drivers whole in both ways. Pressure the ride sharing companies (food delivery is the smaller portion) but kill this government rent seeking. Sheer graft costing the consumer and the driver.

The California situation doesnâ€™t share the whole truth. The law AB 5 that was rolled out was way far reaching and impacted all gig workers in unrelated industries - such as freelance artists, musicians, craftspeople etc. The senator who wrote the law who is featured took Union money to craft the law, and cited Uber and Lyft as her targets but carved out exceptions for these very companies and still passed the law impacting all other genuine gig workers. Unfortunately it was not written well, and wasnâ€™t honest as it didnâ€™t actually prioritize fixing the problems with app based contractors who are really misclassified and should be treated as employees - but rather crippled the entire gig working industry where many artists saw their contracting projects disappear overnight - as people just hired others from outside California to avoid violating AB 5. It also put pressure on small non profits and small businesses to now pay contractors as employees - for instance non profits that put on small indie concerts yay to pay out even a small amount like $50 would now have to set up payroll to pay these folks as employees. This was very frustrating because at the end of the day - the apps were the first to carve exceptions for themselves, and rather than go after that, this senator doubled down on everyone else.

What is weird, and I haven't seen discussed, is how this is basically backwards from how things used to be.  Grubhub would have been a software platform if they started in the 80s or 90s, a delivery management app.  They would have then migrated to a hosted app, then a cloud app, and then a cloud service, taking bigger cuts each time.  Instead, Grubhub came at this from the end game angle where you take everything but the restaurant, the riskiest part, and consume all the possible wealth for the food once prepared.  They could and should easily be just a platform that makes tiny cuts out of millions of transactions to make money, but instead they are strong arming everyone.

I door dashed during the pandemic, there were orders from restaurants that were closed for years in the mall and I called them ten times with pictures of the location being empty and nobody cared. The last day i dashed, i was sent there again. I personally texted the customer to let them know that the restaurant isn't running and I informed customer support. Quitting was so unclimactic all I had to do was cash out my whopping $100 for 12 hrs worth of work (not including gas otherwise its more like $40 left) delete the app and just stop. I miss the people i got to know at several restaurants that were actually running, but I don't miss being sent on ghost missions for zero pay only to be ignored when I report to headquarters. Oh and fun fact us drivers found out that all the premium or bonus offers were rigged so you'd only get orders out of town until the offer is over then suddenly your algorithms reset to your location. We also discovered the more dashers who decline an order the higher the order payout ratchets up. People need to understand door dash gets your money and puts it in a big pool and your tip won't all necessarily go to me. That's why you should make sure to tip your delivery driver cash when they show up to ensure they get the full amount instead of DD. I could go on all day, I had to buy my own bags and cup holders too, taxes were a nightmare and after doing the math I actually lost money dashing between vehicle maintenance and repairs and gas. Also remember door dash will try to stack two or more orders on their driver's too so even if you pay extra to get it delivered as fast as possible it still could take a while if door dash is making me go from arbys to chipotle and drop off whoever lives closest first. Also another key to remember as a Dasher the suggested route to take is never the fastest or most sensible, you really have to know your city and be able to ignore gps to go take your own shortcuts. Once you start going the gps will try to correct you but after a certain point it gives up lol and sees what path you're taking. Just one last thought as well, please turn on your porch lights and make sure your walkway is clear of snow or toys so your driver doesn't have to worry about slipping while carrying four pizzas and a two liter of Fanta up your property because you live two miles past the papa johns delivery zone.

One thing this segment left out was the phenomenon of â€œghost kitchensâ€.  These exist as a single storefront in the real world, but operate as potentially dozens of fake restaurants on a food delivery app, all of which have the same address and often the same food items too.  The effect of this is a single ghost kitchen taking up huge amounts of space on these apps and artificially outcompeting locally owned restaurants.

I used to work delivery for a restaurant I leave with 5 to 8 out orders at Peak time Drive in a circle within a 2 to 5 Mi radius it would take me 30 40 minutes and I get a tip on most orders plus the per order fee the restaurant give me or they pay for my miles. Plus an hourly wage, sometimes less than minimum, but something. So in a half hour you get probably 5 to 10 dollars in tips ( most tip 10% some way more some don't) 3 to 6 dollars an hour and a bit more in mileage and if it's a per-order fee that can be another five bucks easy. That didn't get better in the two years I continued to deliver afterward. Hopefully, tips are better now..  I also did gig work on Door Dash and Instacart for almost two years on the backside of the pandemic (mostly to just get out of my house for a few hours, and the extra money never hurts). So I have experience doing both sides of that coin. It is MUCH better to be able to set your own hours and not ever having to clean a restaurant to close it at 1:30 a.m.  I also work as a freelance writer, so the independent work part is nothing new for me. You can write these expenses all off in your taxes. There are a lot of benefits of being an independent worker, and I've preferred this route in life for nearly two decades now. You just have to be good at managing your money, which you should be anyway.  I will have to say, I left Door Dash when they made it far easier to get contract violations earlier this year. All a customer had to do was say you delivered the wrong order, no proof, and you are suddenly in trouble. I would find out through the app that I had a violation and you cannot actually appeal it. You're not allowed to call them about it and there is no direct contact for whoever supposedly handles this anywhere. I had two situations where this happened and I could prove that the customer reported false information, but when there is no one to prove that to, there's nothing you can do. That level of disrespect towards drivers is why I stopped Door Dashing entirely.  And then I reported on it in a local paper that I write for...

He asked for a cash tip, and I pulled out $5, which was actually a pretty standard tip for what I got.  He said, "I see more money, give it to me" while he started pushing into the doorway.  I initially said no, but he kept forcing his way further and further into my apartment.  It was to the point where he might be able to close the door behind him and physically be in my apartment.  He never broke eye contact, and I was terrified.  I gave him all my money, and he left.  When I reported him to the app, all they said was, "We will flag him so that he doesn't deliver to you anymore."  I'm grateful for that, but I'm scared for anyone else he delivered to.  All that being said, I actually don't fault him that much.  He was desperate because of what these apps do to their delivery employees.  I didn't report it to the police because part of me felt really bad for him.  The system is beyond broken.

As a delivery driver, I actually reccommend you **don't** tip well up front. These apps pay almost nothing, and they are being subsidized by your generosity. They send out outrageously unprofitable orders, and only pay more than a dollar or two if the order gets turned down too many times. If you give a big tip, they will lump it in with someone else who didn't tip and ordered from super far away, and even if you gave $20 and live right across the street, the driver may still barely make any money on the entire order they were given. Keep your tip to a minimum, and it will increase in value a bit, and then you can make someone's day by increasing it later. This also protects you from "tipping" those people who grab your food, take a picture of it in your driveway, and then drive off with it, or just actively cause problems. Split the savings from not rewarding bad drivers with the good drivers.

I am a single dad who used to have a career in TV operations before streaming channels (like Max, for example!) killed off my industry. I now rely on a couple of "hustles" to raise my son here in California, but the lion's share of my income is from food delivery apps. Here's the thing: these companies have found a way to outsource American jobs TO American workers, sidestepping all labor protections, min wage requirements, etc. AB5 would've given us employee protections, and that is why, according to ballotpedia, the gig app companies actually spent way more to get Prop 22 passed than reported here, to the tune of $250,000,000.00! And while I applaud LWT for bringing some attention to the tip issue, there is an anti "tipping culture" movement out there based on a wholly erroneous perception that app drivers get paid an hourly wage by the companies. We do not! Before tip, a delivery of 5 miles or so pays roughly $3.50. Keeping in mind that gas is $5.15/gal, consider the cost to drive that 5 miles, then 5 miles back home, plus the cost of insurance, expenses that pop up all the time like tires, wear and tear, etc, in a car that gets roughly 20 MPG. There have been times that I have delivered food to rich people (who often don't tip as well as those stoners who are absolutely STOKED that you brought them tacos from Jack In The Box at 3 AM) and literally PAID for the privilege! So if you want to be a truly decent human being when using food delivery apps, tip your driver based on that information instead of calculating based on the size of your order, or the perceived value the app provides. I worked for a food delivery service in college in 1999 that worked like DoorDash (we had contracts for about 30 restaurants and used FCC-licensed radios and a dispatcher). I learned there are some specific rules that can make this type of service business profitable. #1 Every delivery had a set fee for delivery - $3 no matter what (100% of that went to the driver)  #2 Specific delivery area - if you were outside of the very well defined delivery area for a chosen restaurant, you couldn't order. #3 Drivers were expected to double check the order at the restaurant to make sure all items were in the bag. #4 Tips were chosen and added by the customer upon delivery, not in advance (all of the tip went to the driver).  #5 You needed a vehicle to do deliveries - not a bicycle or scooter.

John forgot to mention the tax consequence for the people doing deliveries. Because they are self employed that means they have to pay self employment tax on their profits which is 15%. Say that after expenses are taken the net profit is $15,000. The self employment tax on that is $2,250 on top of regular income tax from other sources of income like a W-2 job. I don't think many delivery drivers have that money to pay for taxes and many of them are not even aware of self employment tax.

In Brazil, the Central Bank blocked Meta (facebook, whatsapp, instagram) from releasing their payment systems. The reason: the Central Bank was about to release a free to use payment system that any e-payment operator would be able to use - also for free - and people would be able to pay Facebook from PayPal with no problem. What they did was to democratize not only people's access to payments but also democratize the corporate side since now a huge company has no advantage over a small one in the payment area.  I know for a fact that the same people who did PIX work is now working on a PIX version for delivery - not only of food but also flowers, beer, usb cables. You see ... capitalism is not all that bad - even Karl Marx was a great admire of the system - but for it to work the State (Governement) must regulate and keep it healthy - as Adam Smith described a long time ago.   Adam Smith is often blamed by things he never said like "capitalism iequals unregulated financial system and markets" - words spoken in the 20th century by the Austrian economist von Hayek and his American pupil Milton Friedman. The Scotish Moral Philosopher (Adam Smith) wrote two books: "The Theory of Moral Sentments" and "The Wealth of Nations". The harmonization of these two works is known in Germany as "Das Adam Smith Probleme".  There's an old lecture on YouTube where I not only learned the joke that ends the above paragraph but also about the problem and perhaps a solution. In "Moral Sentments" Smith argues that humans have an urge to be liked and respected and that keeps human acting with civility. In "Wealth of Nations" he argues that this urge to be liked keeps the people who sell stuff from setting the price too high and the people who buy stuff from paying too little - because the seller wants to be liked by the buyer and the buyer - because that person also wants to be liked by the seller - doesn't want to pay so little the seller ends up going bankrupt.  Adam Smith's prescription for a healthy capitalism is "fair and free competition". For competition to be fair and free, Smith argued, the State must interfere and regulate finance and the economy. The great economist - who was also greatly admired by Karl Marx - also reminded readers that there are some areas of human life that should not be framed in the "fair and free competition" system - like guaranteeing what we now call "basic human rights and human dignity".  During Smith's life the West Indies Company held the monopoly of ultramarine commerce and Smith's never ceased his mental fight against such deviation from "free and fair competition".   -----  I made the post a little longer to explain particularly to Americans that things like universal health care  are not antithetical to capitalistm - they are only seen in that way in the US and only after WWII.

Damn man, that is all true. I've been an Uber and Doordash driver for 6 years in California, I remember Proposition 22 and Assembly Bill 5 that Prop 22 was a carve-out for. The gig companies absolutely bombarded me and everyone else with phone calls, text messages, paper mail, email, voice-mails, there was spam inside my Uber/Doordash driver apps, even the merchants were complaining to me that they couldn't even get a single order out through the app without having to press "Yes I support Proposition 22" on every order. They hired astroturf companies whose goal was to inundate social media with fake support for Prop 22, I saw it on the Uber and Doordash subreddits, Facebook groups, even fucking Discord. They paid a LOT of money to dupe Californians into thinking Prop 22 was a good thing.   Anyway rant aside, yes, it is absolutely true about the ratings we recieve from customers, those ratings can easily either get the amount and quality/pay of orders sent to you reduced, or get you deactivated altogether. "Fired" in the usual sense of the word.   And yes, they really want us as independent contractors, that was the entire point of Prop 22, that we don't become employees and therefore gain all the usual labor law rights like the right to a minimum wage, unemployment insurance, workman's comp, reimbursement for gas and vehicle maintenance etc. It was pretty underhanded to say the least.   Lastly yes, the tips are really important! We don't have a right to a minimum wage. So on Doordash for instance, Doordash pays the delivery driver 2 dollars per order and each order takes approximately 20 minutes to complete, so that comes out to earning 6 dollars per hour -- before taxes expenses -- which we also pay 100% of the cost of. We aren't reimbursed for any of that from the apps. That's why we call him  2 Dollar Tony. Uber is slightly better than Doordash for pay, but your tip really does make ALL the difference between making less than the federal minimum wage, or above it.
