I delivered for SkipTheDishes years ago when my city was the Canadian company's test market before UberEats came to our market.  SkiptheDishes took cards thru the website, but customers could also pay cash.  Drivers had a cash float, and when a cash order came thru, drivers paid the restaurant, and customers paid us the cash for the order plus a fee and tip.  When UberEats entered the market, most skipthedishes drivers (who we knew each other from waiting in restaurants together) noticed that we'd get huge cash orders that would have you deliver to a weird location.  I was sent with $60 of sushi to a Uhaul store at midnight and $75 in pizza to a yoga studio at 1am Saturday night.  When this happened, Skip had to reimburse drivers for the cash we spent at the restaurant, and drivers kept the food (or it happened so much with such huge orders, that I made regular stops at a church where I knew homeless men slept).  This cost SkiptheDishes so much that they pulled out of our market.  They didn't want to give up taking cash orders, because it gave them access to customers that the other new companies couldn't service since they only took orders that paid by card.......so who was placing those cash orders?ğŸ¤”

Literally there were fast food stalls in the days of ancient Rome. This is good and works for our species, bulk food prep cuts costs and maximizes food eaten, reducing wastes. Worked for Postmates back in '17. It was the closest I've been to actual slavery in a work situation. I understand a little has changed since then, but there was no consideration for vehicle wear and tear; I drove through heavy storms, and in my area at the time, that meant massive potholes on freeways and surface roads. I had to spend thousands during that time on repairs above and beyond mere maintenance. Further, because the way the business is structured, you cannot collect unemployment for any reason other than the loss or destruction of your car, because if your car still works, all you have to do is turn on the app and you technically have a job. On top of all that, the money and tips were sh*t [and in a very affluent delivery area]. It was the beginning of a very frustrating and financially devastating period for me. Luckily, after a few years had passed, there were two massive class-action suits against Postmates, and I recovered about $1000 from them. After having worked for one, I will never use a food delivery app.

I think it's easy to get "outraged" by the inequities of a marginalized gig economy job. And easy to gin up sympathy. But it's a job akin to what mowing lawns was and no longer is. Or shoveling snow. No one is supposed to be doing something like this during a hurricane. It's risky done on bicycles (as has been being a bike messenger for 50 years). It's not meant to pay a living wage, have health care coverage, or even be something a serious adult would entertain doing. We need to be honest with ourselves...food delivery has been and always will be a marginalized job sought by those with few options. Frankly, the same goes for so many jobs, including enlisting in the military, if we're being honest, here, evidenced by the disproportionate number of poor and minorities who enlist (and I was one of them).  Frankly, this whole piece is a bit lightweight, not really worthy of the energy expended. What's next? I'm an independent professional commercial photographer.  Grubhub and Ubereats photoshoots have been a massive part of my business for several years, and helped keep my business alive during the shutdown of the last few years because other work in my area has been very difficult for me to obtain.  However, the rates that the apps pay is generally less than what is now normal for professional commercial photography (Doordash wanted to pay less than half of what the other two were already paying, so I said no to them).  I don't know what they are charging the restaurants for the photoshoots, but you can be darned sure that it's more than what they are paying me, and I refuse to believe that they aren't charging the restaurants for photoshoots.  A lot of the photoshoots where I'm assigned, the assignments are left as unscheduled, and I find quite a lot of the restaurant owners are very reluctant to have me in to photograph the food because unless that food has been already sold to a customer and is immediately served to that customer after I photograph it (I make sure that waitstaff let the customers know that the food is being photographed on its way to them from the kitchen, allowing the customers to opt-out), the restaurant cannot legally sell it (and yes, my work policy is that I never touch the food until it is my food that is going into my mouth, but I can't say the same for any other photographers).  So the restaurant owner will often see this kind of advertising cost as not useful to them and will stall scheduling my one-hour photoshoot assignment for a very long time (I've had a few in my area stall for almost two whole years).  I don't get any payment at all unless and until I deliver photos from a photoshoot for the app, and I only get paid for the number of photos that I deliver, regardless of how long it took to communicate with the restaurant, how much I had to spend on gas and highway tolls to get to the photoshoot, or how long the photoshoot took at the restaurant.  Also, if I arrive on time for an appointment and the restaurant is not ready and needs to reschedule, I can only submit a late reschedule fee request (if I was hired directly by the restaurant, it would not be a request, but a contracted fee) once per restaurant, no matter how many times the owners reschedule.  And I've found that to get anywhere near enough photoshoot assignments to maintain my business, I need to make my working radius very wide, and will frequently have to drive for three or four hours to get to the photoshoot locations; I have driven to every corner of my state and halfway across four neighboring states for these assignments, such as driving to Green Bay, WI, one day, then down to Davenport, Iowa, the next day, followed by Chicago and Minneapolis on the next two days, and none of those cities are where I live.  Yes, about half the time I get to take food home with me, but I have yet to form any meaningful business relationships with any of the restaurant owners I've met while doing these assignments, and that's not for a lack of trying.  Please tip the drivers who deliver your food, but remember that there is no tip field anywhere in the app for the photographer who made the photograph that appears next to the menu item in the app.

I worked at a pizza place that went into bankruptcy because of delivery apps. They had lots of orders but barely made a profit. Grubhub took 20% commission plus a fixed $0.25 per order, without any ads or special services. So they tried to get away. They built their own website so you could order and pay online with cheaper prices. They offered additional discounts for ordering on the phone or picking up the food. But people kept choosing the app. It was maddening to watch. In the end, with grocery prices skyrocketing, they had no choice but to significantly raise prices which slashed their customer base.  Another big issue was that they didnâ€™t let us refuse individual orders. You could either mark the restaurant as â€œclosedâ€ or you had to take every order with a maximum timeframe of 90 minutes. This made planning super difficult. Cause you might be perfectly able to do x amount of orders and deliver on time if they come one after the other but not if you get 5 at the same time. Or if oneâ€™s to a remote area. I worked the phone and to cancel specific orders I had to call each customer, then call Grubhub, then confirm the cancellation on our device. Or I had to call people up to confirm a delivery later than 90 minutes. No one has time for that when youâ€™re already at capacity. So we usually tried to somehow fulfill every order often resulting in longer wait times, annoyed customers, bad reviews and the employees working at their limit. But the alternative wouldâ€™ve been to completely close down the app during the busiest hours which is just not possible when youâ€™re already operating on such a narrow profit margin.  All that is to say - if your favourite place has another option to order please use it, it really helps them out!

I delivered pizza starting in 1994, and delivered until i became disabled. It was often my main job (because look, where i live, in 2005 i made 7.50 an hour, 1.25 per "run" (order. On Fridays I'd often have 3 orders per trip, each order was considered a run. Don't ask me was it wasn't categorized as per order) and while the mileage was screwing IMO, I'd get oil changes, tires, and i even got 3 tune ups in the course of 12 years - then i switched from papa John's (because i went back to school and they weren't willing to accommodate me working part time, despite HIRING me part time)  to pizza hut.i took a small pay cut, and only got a 1.25 a run (PJ had increased to, iirc,1.40) but they were flexible, had a smaller delivery area, better benefits - and i had THE best managers I've ever had, hands down. ALL of the managers. At one point, i dislocated my shoulder and was working with it in a brace, and was limited to 4 hour shifts - no problem for them, they were just happy to keep me. When i started my very unjustly journey to disability, they spent MONTHS working with me, finding or at least twice CREATING jobs i could do as my medical restrictions increased. And thing is, why my managers were exactly that awesome, they were ALLOWED to be, and were hired TO be that awesome, and were supported by THEIR managers, on up the line.   The ONLY problem i had with delivering back then is that so many people thought the delivery fee was out to. In fact, the last i delivered,  *10 CENTS* of that delivery was passed on to me (as part of the "run" - but that money was supposed to go entirely to maintaining my car and paying for gas) a lot of it, i think fifty cents, went towards my hourly. A larger part went towards paying the people who worked the call center.   I once suggested to the district manager (my managers managers manager) that they put on receipts or SOMEWHERE that the delivery fee wasn't a tip and that NO WE DID NOT MAKE $16-20 an hour. (It was a meeting about why morale was so bad and how to fix it. It was so bad because they'd raised to deliver few, so tips dropped, and no one had gotten their expected raises, this new DM said the company couldn't afford it. We were a small franchise... anyway, the jerk was VERY offended I'd suggest that, not sure why, but he kept trying to get us to do trust falls and similar, and we all kept telling we got along with EACH OTHER great, we'd just taken a huge monetary hit and that's the only reason for low morale. The idiot wanted us to return to being happy without even listening to why weren't - he didn't last much longer, and the owner listened to the "letting customers know the delivery fee wasn't a tip" thing, and it helped. As did him NEVER AGAIN advertise as "make $16â€20/ hour' - from then on, he advertise "starting hourly plus tips". But i know why that jerk didn't want to actually inform customers that the delivery fee wasn't a tip - some people might not order. Not many, but some. Except deals or coupons or something say that same pizza should be 12 or so. Even if cheese has tripled in price over the last year, and most meats doubled and etc, can't raise the price of the PIZZA (go look at pizza prices starting in the 80s. One place inflation didn't really affect consumer prices)   When grub hub started, i was PISSED. I knew what was coming. No one i knew listened to me - I'm a Cassandra... But yeah, I'm disabled. *The American dream:*  - Spend your entire youth studying hard and working a student job to get the best start your adult life with the best chances on the job market and some decent savings for your first flat (no time for hobbies and friends)  - Spend the next ten to twenty years of your life working your butt off all day to rise up the corporate ladder to a management or senior specialist position or to save enough money to start your own innovative business (Still no time for hobbies and friends)  - Make a lot of money, buy a big house and a fancy car and start a family that you won't have time for because, while you finally have money you wished for now, you're still a manager, senior specialist or businesses owner, those occupations demand long hours and are exhausting AF and you gotta keep on working for at least another decade or two if you don't want to lose it all again! (Still no time for hobbies and friends)  - Retire. Finally you have time to be a parent, but ooops, your kids are all grown-up, have already moved out and are now either caught up in the same grind, or in addiction(s). Either way, they don't care much about you because growing up, they never felt you care about them. Your partner might still be around if you're lucky! On the plus side, now you definitely have enough time and money to _pursue hobbies, relax_ and _enjoy the day._ If you still remember what these words mean. (Now you also time to hang out with friends, if you still have any)   *The American reality:*  - Spend your entire youth working multiple student jobs to afford your tuition fees (no time for hobbies and friends. Barely time to study, even)  - Spend the next decades (five or six till retirement) working your butt off all day (and often all night, too) just to barely scrape by paycheck to paycheck without the slightest chance to make a career or save up enough money to start a business. You can't afford your car, but you NEED it and you'll never afford to own your home. And you're still paying back your student debts. If you start a family at all, that's by accident and only makes your life infinitely harder. (no time for hobbies and friends)  - Retire long before you can afford a decent rent because your body just can't take it anymore. Now you _would_ have time for hobbies, but you can't afford the necessary equipment and your body is too much of a wreck for any hobby involving physical activity (which all the most affordable hobbies do). Your friends, if you had any, have probably all died from the unforgiving hard work, from their use of alcohol and other drugs, or from (gambling) debt-induced depression. Some of them even turned to a life of crime in their despair and got arrested or died. You're pretty much just waiting to die also, suffering in poverty in your overworked body broken down from decades of exploitative labor with no sick leave, no worker's protection and no worker's compensation!   Everyone still puts all the effort into the American dream, but fewer and fewer people get to reap its promised rewards!

Just as an addition: as a former Uber driver, I can tell you a score of three stars is considered "failure" and if you get three, 3 star reviews you are put on suspension and if you get any additional three-star ratings you're fired. Even one single three star rating will knock down your overall rating (a percentage of 100) to into the 70s and getting it back up to 100 is nearly impossible. 100% drivers will have more jobs pop up. Lower scores reduce the amount of deliveries you can choose from or even are offered. So both tips and ratings are important. If someone doesn't rate you that can become a problem, if it were to happen too often even though it is not in your control.

Uber Eats allows consumers to "pre-tip" the drivers and we drivers can see that. We get to decide if what you are willing to pay us for the delivery is worth our time. We are under no obligation to accept your order if we feel it's too low for the time taken (that's what gig work means, we have a choice). That's why many customers can't seem to find an Uber Eats driver to pick up their food. You are in a bidding war with customers that do pre-tip. I myself have been pinged with coffee delivery orders that are 30 miles away for $4 with no pre-tip. We can't afford to count on your good graces after the fact to make it worth while. Furthermore, the 20% tip rule doesn't work for delivery drivers the way it works for wait-staff, who can service multiple tables in an hour. I am stuck servicing one customer for the duration of the delivery. In short, if you want to know how much to tip your delivery driver, I suggest "the maximum amount you are willing to pay someone so you don't have to put on pants and get it yourself." Then hope the driver agrees with you. If not, you can now put on your own pants and save yourself that money.

Worked in a dark kitchen in Paris back in August 2022. This is where the burgers that people order on food delivery apps gets madeâ€”not a restaurant, just a kitchen that opens straight into the street with no seating area. I had to prepare the sauces and pack the orders into their bags, and the two Sri Lankan cooks made the burgers; we had to work at an industrial pace, especially on weekends, and at least I only worked a few hours a day.  The delivery guys outside, most of whom didn't speak a lick of French and barely more English, were always very anxious about getting their orders as fast as possible because if they were late the apps' algorithms made them less likely to be selected again and they risked losing tips (even though tipping isn't part of the culture here because personnel services are paid for by the employer). I'm also guessing these guys didn't have much of a choice working as "self-employed" on these apps given how I doubt any of them had residency or work permits which would've allowed them to get other jobs. The boss told us to put a table in front of the entrance where we put orders to prevent the delivery guys from coming in to prevent altercations. It was a harsh look at how Uberized capitalism treats vulnerable people such as undocumented migrants like cogs in its machine to satisfy customer impulses it largely creates.

It seems like the main function of apps in today's market is to paper over worker exploitation.  Which is annoying, because food delivery can potentially be a more environmentally sustainable way to get good food to people. If I buy chicken from the grocery store, I have to store it, usually for more than a week unless I want to eat the same thing every day. That means I need to freeze it, either before or after cooking it if I want it to stay good, which means disposable plastic bags. And driving too and from the store is quite inefficient too, while walking to it would be great, most people don't live within easy walking distance of the store. While upgrading our cities so more people can walk to every place they regularly need to go is something we should do, it will take quite a long time, and before it gets done we are likely to have drones that can deliver far more efficiently. Delivered food can be sent in small enough quantities that the packaging doesn't need to last more than a few days, so it can be made of properly biodegradable (or safe for incineration in a waste to energy plant) materials. Food can be shipped in bulk to restaurants, keeping packaging too a minimum, and they can have less food thrown away to spoilage the food consumption of large number of people is more consistent than a single person or small family. If we set the system up well, it will cost less and have lower environmental impact than even cooking at home. But right now the system is set up to profit app companies at the expense of everyone else and the planet.

I delivered for Dominos and later an Italian restaurant in college - my weekly hours anywhere between 20 hours to 60, all "part-time" with no benefits - and during the pandemic I delivered for Pizza Hut. In 2021 I tried Doordash while searching for a better paying job - Anything that wasn't food related, I have too many literal burns scars on my arms for customers who need to have their dinner Now.  I can say a lot of trash about Dominos and other restaurants and how shitty they are to their employees, but at least I was getting some pay, and I could get some comfort and community with my employees after an inevitable customer decided they were more entitled to life than us.  Doordash though? I actually ended up quitting after only maybe a month of that. The only way to make any amount of money was to drive dangerously. I used to routinely deliver four to ten orders at a time back in college - I knew the delivery area and could pair orders up efficiently. But doordash doesn't have a delivery area, they just have what is next, and if something cropped up in the middle of a delivery, a notification pops up and asks if you want to accept it - while you are Driving. If I didn't accept it, it counted that as a rejection, and rejecting orders was a negative mark on your account. There was no guarantee though that the new order was on the same route I was on, so if I just accepted it without looking I ran the risk of accepting an order that I could not safely get to within the time allotted - Another negative mark.  I am impressed by drivers who are able to make that system work, and deeply angry that it is set so against them. Ten years in customer service, and I will always side with the worker over the customer, but I know that most of the time? Customers don't really understand how shitty the situation is - so many tell me they didn't even know drivers rely on tips, or that anything less than five stars can lead to hours reductions and employee loss, which negatively affects their performance in a fucked up cycle that only the company could actually stop, but clearly don't care to. Just, any working model that requires your employees to work three jobs just to survive? That's not acceptable.

This model has never made sense to me.  Here's a fun exercise:  Look up the price of an item you want for pick-up in person.  Then order it through a delivery app.  Calculate the difference between the two.  Now, consider whether you would get in your car, drive to the vendor, pick up that item, and deliver it to some random place in your town -- for that amount of money. (note 1)  The answer is probably, "Nahh.."  OK.  What makes you think anyone else would, either?  Given that, how do you think this scales to all the people doing this in your city, and every other city where it exists?  Like I said:  This model has never made sense to me.  (NOTE 1: And that's assuming that 100% of the difference goes to you.  Which it doesn't.  But let's ignore that for now.)

I work at a restaurant in a small town with few Doordash drivers.... so the bulk of our Doordash orders are picking up their own food. And because they are paying a premium to order through the online service, they largely are not tipping. I implore people to just call us, as our time estimates will be more accurate and the food will be cheaper... but people are so obsessed with ordering things online that they will do it even when there is absolutely no benefit to themselves.  And speaking of time estimates, the apps are terrible at this. They claim to use fancy algorhythm math to add more time during high volume but this is completely a lie. If 15 online orders come in at the same time, they will all have the same wait time. And that doesn't even factor in the orders we get in the restaurant. We cook all of our food to order and typically add about 3 minutes per order. So if its Friday night and there are 20 tickets on the line, it quicky becomes an hour wait. And there is no way to get the apps to work with us on this. They still send drivers a message 15 minutes after the order came in that the food is ready. The result is angry drivers and angry customers.   And if the drivers reports to the app that the food is not ready... we get an angry call right in the middle of the rush, from a call center that probably usually handles credit collection asking us why our food isnt ready.... to which my stock reply is: fix your software!  These apps also have a terrible problem of not actually confirming that orders have been processed by the restaurant point of sale. So if the internet connection is spotty or if for whatever reason the POS is down... no ticket is printed and then we get a driver or customer showing up 20 minutes later wanting to know why they got a message saying "the food is ready" but there is no food. Because we never got the order. Or sometimes randomly the order will print out exactly at the time it was supposed to be ready instead of when it was placed. And dont even get me started on these apps reporting us closed when we are open or open when we are closed, randomly turning on menu items we have turned off, or that Doordash embeds itself into Google search results so that people think they are accessing our "website" when its actually Doordash, posting incredibly wrong wait times for food, and just generally misleading our customers about every aspect of our business. If I was the owner I would just turn them off. We had better sales, better tips, and happier customers before Doordash. I dont see the upside.

The correct tip for delivery apps varies slightly based on state, but if you can't do at least $1 per mile between you and the store you ordered from, you can't afford the service. To equate it into terms of waitstaff tips, $1 per mile =10% tip, $1.50 per mile =15% tip, and $2 per mile =20% tip.

I drove for Uber from the very beginning and rarely received any tips, and the option didn't even exist. The idea was supposed to be a cashless/tipless system, and the pay was good enough for a gig economy job without having to hustle the customers for tips. However, somewhere along the way, or it was always in their plan, Uber got greedy and decided to cut drivers' pay and significantly hike the cost for customers, while also expecting customers to chip in for the drivers' pay.  Furthermore, it's a supply vs. demand market, and a lot of people suddenly want to become "service industry" workers at their convenience, considering that almost every household has cars. Well, guess what? You shot yourselves in the foot because Uber has the leverage to set whatever pay they want as long as drivers keep piling in. It could be $1 plus tip tomorrow, and some people will still drive (and complain) while expecting users to make up the difference.  The users already pay a 30% marked-up price and an 18% service charge, while restaurants pay almost a third to Uber for every order. Many drivers seriously need to find other jobs so that the remaining ones can have the leverage to get better pay. And don't compare this to pizza delivery; pizzas don't get marked up by 30% + 18% service charge when they arrive at your door. Additionally, I don't believe many people tip on top of the automatically charged 18% tip at a restaurant.  And don't tell me that Uber losing money justifies their actions. They also shot themselves in the foot with foolish, greedy, and questionable business tactics. The pursuit of global domination is an ongoing battle, and they will continue to incur losses in that regard. Instead, they should concentrate on a few areas and foster a loyal customer base by prioritizing the well-being of their drivers through fair compensation.

They set a $12 minimum per order, if you subscribe for "free" delivery and "reduced" service fees.. But then, they set the prices on everything on the menu to make it almost impossible to order anything for the $12 minimum.. For example, they will set many items at $11.99.. And nothing else on the menu set for less than at least $3 - 4, but most often $8 or more..   Then, even if you magage to find a lucky combination to make just around the $12 minimum, which sometimes means add-ons that you don't really want.. Between their fees, even with a "free" delivery subscription, and your tip.. You end up paying somewhere between 40% and even up to even 70% more than the price of the item! So it's rigged to cost you around $18 or more for a $12 order, no matter what.. And that's only if you are stingy on the tip.. And if you don't pay for a "free delivery" subscription, it costs astronomically more!   There are so few restaurants anymore that offer traditional delivery with their own drivers.. But even those few that do, now set their prices and minimums so high, that the most you can save on a direct order from the restaurant instead of using a delivery app, is maybe a dollar or two.. Which is probably their way of trying to make a little more profit to offset the exorbitant losses that they incur with the delivery services..   So these days, regarding using a delivery app versus ordering directly from the restaurant, it's basically 6 one way and half a dozen of the other!   For this reason, I am not completely feeling sorry for the restaurants either! They are free to refuse these delivery apps and go back to old way.. Keep a delivery driver on staff and take normal orders, without jacking up their own prices and delivery fees to be almost as bad as the delivery apps!   Bottom line, to order delivery these days is just plain highway robbery! I don't see how you can say that the customers are benefiting in any way..

Shipt made the false claims that they didn't have the infrastructure to deal with keeping track of the pay increases and other changes. Then on 1/20/24, I sustained a pinched nerve in my back and I haven't been able to do any work since then. Well, I have done 2x orders on the Shipt app, but with my pinched nerve in my back and they both took me over 50% longer than they used to before my injury. Because they were both outside of the Seattle city limits, Shipt was able to get away with paying me $9 and $6 respectively for each order and only the $9 order tipped me anything. Luckily both gave me a 5-star review, but that is not a sustainable income. Disabled people (temporarily or permanently) are not always able to do every kind of job, but when you are desperate to work so that you keep a roof over your head, these jobs can be a life saver. However, when $5 is the average pay out that these big app companies are allowed to get away with paying to the gig workers, then something needs to change.  Changing the laws back to allow them to operate as they were before is counter intuitive to paying workers proper wages, but raising the guaranteed pay for gig workers also poses the problem that we are facing in Seattle, where some app companies just decided to cut the city out of their business plans. So if you were able to afford to have your groceries shopped and delivered to you, then please think about your shopper/deliverer. They are human also and they deserve to be paid for doing you the favor of delivering to your door. Of the 6,388 customers that I helped on the Shipt app, I averaged 30% of them tipped anything at all. Most restaurants would either become buffett style or close down. And they are just delivering to your table within the same restaurant that you went to. Gig app workers are delivering thru traffic and weather to your door! The least you can do is give them a couple of extra bucks for all they did for you. $2 goes a long way for gig workers. 14:00 Crap. Now you've given them ideas, John! Give it a month and we'll probably see a few dozen of them...  21:38 and a bit before. That's the point, though. Listen to anyone who raves about the greatness of capitalism and they'll tell you how it lowers prices. This is all of the stuff that they DON'T say, because that's not what they're trained to think about. They only know the talking points, not the context behind them. Yeah, capitalism lowers prices, but HOW does it lower prices? It doesn't cut out middle-men, but adds more, and those "more" have to be paid by someone. It doesn't use a cheaper version of the same quality ingredients. It doesn't require fewer workers doing the actual work, though it regularly tries to cut labor and increase workloads without increasing wages or other benefits.  When you get down to it, capitalism stiffs labor in favor of private profits. In cases like this, which we've seen in other cases like with Amazon, they sell low at a loss to drive competition out, corner the market so that there's no competition, and then raise prices higher than they were before. None of the other inputs of labor or material change. None of the middle men get cut out, but more are added (warehouses require maintenance and other costs, and workers have to manage their stock. Drivers move stuff between warehouses, producers and consumers).  The whole point is "line go up," which the people who rave about the greatness of capitalism also point to as "proof" that capitalism is great. Not because they like the fact that workers get stiffed ("workers who do those jobs aren't ambitious enough, are lazy, etc etc etc, but I'm a temporarily embarrassed millionaire who can use that business model if I just put in more effort"). Not because prices go down temporarily, or even over the long term (as inflation rises and wages do not, as prices rise and wages do not, etc). Not for any reason other than that those people who rave about capitalism think that they just need to put in more effort to be one of the people standing at the top of the pile of corpses counting stacks of cash. They are willing to put up with temporary "humiliation" and hardship if there's even the barest sliver of a chance that they'll "make their fortune" or whatever trope you want to use. They'll make any excuse, accept any talking point, and do everything they can to smash arguments against their hopes and dreams of being the scum that rises to the top, not through contextually appropriate facts or solid logic and reasoning, but through sheer CULT loyalty and desperation.  Capitalism creates desperation, even/especially in the people brainwashed to think that it's even "good." Capitalism does exactly one thing that's good: socialize production. Because what came before capitalism was feudalism, where individual artisans did small-scale work that didn't really meet the needs of society (but met the desires of the aristocracy somewhat). Consolidating and socilaizing labor increases productivity and innovation, but the consolidation of PROFITS does not, nor does having someone standing at the top acting like they're a "stable genius." Consolidating and socializing labor made other things possible for labor to start doing, like organize and fight for better conditions. But just because capitalism led to one thing being done better doesn't mean that people should desperately fight to perpetuate it. There is no "good" that capitalism does that other systems can't do more or better. Even statism is better, just not so much for the people who are desperate to stand at the top; for them it's worse, but for everyone else it's better because they're no longer desperate just to survive...depending on the starting conditions before statism. History doesn't start at the implementation of a system, but the people who rave about capitalism would have everyone believe otherwise.  Also depending on how other systems interact with it. Interventionism doesn't cease to exist and allow opposition to the established powers have a fair shot, but the people who rave about capitalism would have everyone believe otherwise, or somehow excuse with "well, they couldn't handle the competition," as though that means anything deeper than "I guess that small business couldn't compete with Walmart. That just means that small business was the worst system in history." Because that's what their arguments boil down to, except that in real life Walmart doesn't start cold wars that could end hundreds of millions of lives, or twist reality to make people believe that their competition eats babies, etc etc etc. The US, UK etc all do that and worse in the name of maintaining the status quo.

Thereâ€™s also a â€œlabelâ€ function for each address- you can go through your history or use the labels as you go.  So now, many drivers will, after each delivery, use the â€œlabelâ€ function to note the address and how the delivery went. Some people share this information with others, if a customer is especially creepy or cheap, or if the address is difficult to deliver to.  It sucks that people who genuinely canâ€™t afford to tip much, or need help with a lot of heavy items, can get screwed by this sort of labeling system. But having delivered off and on before and during the pandemic, I can say that using labels in this way lets me not waste time on orders that are not worth it financially. Something to think about: I'm all in favor of direct democracy. But it clearly, in these cases, it has some unintended consequences when major corporations can spend hundreds of millions on what are at least misleading, and in some cases, even false ads to support their positions. At the cost of even more money to the workers, but also the consumers and small businesses. Many of these ballot initiatives are so confusing in their wording the voters don't really know what they're voting for; they're set up to sound innocuous or even good for us when they're really not. And worse yet, like the 7/8 rule (that's already in court, but may possibly be upheld), when the voters realize what they've really got and get "buyer's remorse," they're horrendously difficult to undo. Finally, often they're done this way in order to by-pass real, democratic scrutiny that they might actually get from either legislators or governors who might veto them for very good reasons.  The bottom line: caveat emptor. Look at your ballot BEFORE you vote and clearly understand not just what it states, nor even what's implied, but the consequences of such initiatives when you vote. Because an informed electorate is absolutely necessary if we are to keep our democracy.

Related note about feedback and ratings: most retail establishments give customers the ability to fill out surveys for feedback.  And when I worked retail, we had customers give us negative reviews all the time for things completely out of our control - things like corporate modifying the phone system so you don't get to speak to a human being anymore (not our decision, we have no control over that), the website being down or having misleading/outdated information, or even things like we did everything right but a different store in the chain did everything wrong so now here's the chance for the customer to unload.  Please, any customer reading this: FEEDBACK DOES NOT WORK THAT WAY.  When you submit a complaint like that, it goes against the scorecard of whatever register person you interacted with and NOBODY else.  If you take issue with the manager, another store, or corporate, you CANNOT leave feedback like that to get your message across.  You're just ruining the career and livelihood of innocent minimum-wage worker who was unlucky enough to get you.  I've been in meetings with upper management trying to defend the yearly raises of employees who received such feedback and it is an uphill struggle against pointy-haired bosses.  Bosses and corporate don't parse the differences in feedback or have any understanding of nuance.  The customer-facing employees already have to deal with enough psychopaths and sociopaths without having to deal well-meaning people submitting a negative review because they believe they're reviewing the store or another third-party instead of the person directly in front of them.  In any retail setting, or apps like in this video, your feedback will only ever impact the person you interacted with.

TIP! At least $10. (Yes, despite all the raised prices and fees--don't punish the driver.) The real story is far grimmer than what's even covered here. It's dark, man. Delivery drivers can literally lose money on deliveries if the tip isn't robust. If you don't tip, it's like being okay with a slave serving you.   Things not covered in this piece: huge percentage of drivers who rent their car from the delivery platforms or from other related apps (so you don't break even until late in the day if you pay daily, or mid-week if you pay weekly); delayed paydays so drivers can end up homeless while they wait for payment--and lose their rental; limits on hours; being forced to take bad deliveries which will be a loss (not worth time/gas)--lest we upset the algorithm and get no more orders for the day/night.... I could go on, unfortunately.

When I moved states to be closer to my wife's family, there was a time that a Food & Grocery Delivery app was my only source of income. I'd often work 13 hour days, 65 to 72 hours a week, earning an average of about $10.50 an hour, not counting gas and vehicle expenses.  The Independent-Contractor issue is a big one that needs reforming for people who find themselves doing this work full-time. I ended up in the hospital after injuring my back on the job, and had no way to access unemployment or workman's comp as I was 'self-employed' despite signing an exclusivity contract to not work for another food delivery app and signing up for a tier that would guarantee me better payout stability ($9 an hour guarantee) in return for working at least 35 hours a week.  If you're signing exclusivity paperwork, you're not really an 'independent' contractor, and there should be workplace protections.

This reminds me of the way corporations treated blue collar workers, before the organized labor movement gained collective bargaining, when President Roosevelt signed the National Labor Relations Act (aka the Wagner Act) into law on July 5, 1935. Before THAT, workers were basically servants to upper management. They were paid horrible wages, expected to work overtime for no increased pay, no vacation time, no sick leave, no way to address any grievances. Also no kind of health insurance whatsoever, So if they did get sick, not only did they not get paid for missing work, but all medical expenses had to come out of their own pocket. Basically whatever their bosses wanted to do to them, they had to just keep working and take it, if they wanted to keep their jobs.

As someone that has been a Dasher (both full and part time) for almost 2 years, I appreciate you doing this story. People have already commented on the abysmal $2 DD pays its drivers per order, so I wanna throw something else out there.  You mentioned the star rating system affecting job flow and such. This is true for Doordash in the sense that if you get too many negative marks they will deactivate you.  Actual job flow is more influenced by your acceptance rate. Over a rolling 100 delivery offers, they track your % of accepting said offers. There are tiers at 50%, 70% and 90% that affect how often you get orders and in some cases how often you get "high paying" orders. This causes an unstoppable spiral to low acceptance rate and therefore fewer offers just by existing. To elaborate, when DD sends an offer it shows the overall pay for that delivery as well as the mileage (to the restaurant for pickup, and the delivery. It will NOT include coming back to your zone). If you accept an offer that pays anything less than $1 per mile, you are losing money. In some places, it's even harsher because fuel economy is worse due to traffic patterns and whether it's rural/city driving etc.  So basically, in order to keep your acceptance rate (and therefore offer frequency) high you have to accept offers that will be a net loss to you. If you "cherry pick" offers and only accept fiscally reasonable ones, your acceptance rate will be low (full disclosure, mine has floated between 10-20% for months now) and you run the risk of being at the end of the line for delivery offers. And those that are left by the time you get them are ones that other drivers have probably passed over due to crappy pay:miles ratio.  This hurts not only you as a driver but the customer as well, because they're stuck either waiting for a driver to accept their order or it won't get picked up at all. The only way to be sure you'll get a decent delivery time is if you tip well, on top of paying already high prices. It's a really crappy system.
This is what is called Crowd Sourced Labor. Some of it is good, some of it marginal. Everyone should be paid a salary with performance bonuses.

Thank you! As a DD driver I agree with all of your points and most importantly it's great that someone with your following is educating the customers. I don't think that they realize that we don't see any of those delivery fees or that they're rating us not the food.   A big complaint people have is when their order takes a lot longer than they think it should. There can be several reasons for this and some of them are outside of the driver's control.   There may not be a driver close to the restaurant and they may have to drive a couple of miles in heavy traffic to get there.   Fast food restaurants prioritize drive thru orders first, dine in orders second, and delivery third. I have waited over 20 mins for food to be ready at the McDonalds by the interstate during the lunch rush.   It's not always possible but in order to make money doing this a lot of drivers try to avoid taking orders that pay out less than $1/mile. If you didn't tip or tipped low then your food might be ready but sitting around as one driver after the other refuses the order. Then DD will combine your order with an order from someone who tips well enough to make the combined order worth taking and you have the further delay while the driver picks up two orders from two different restaurants and then has to deliver to two different locations. Never has the interpretation of tip as To Insure Prompt service been more true even though the higher dipper is penalized by this with the delay caused by the driver having to make an additional stop.   Finally, GPS sucks in places and between people not having visible house numbers and sometimes giving the wrong address it can take time to actually find you. Do you live on Something Street and accidentally put in Something Drive? Did you want it delivered to your job and instead of asking someone in the office what the street address is just put a pin in the map that actually goes to the place next door or a block away? Are you not answering your phone when the driver calls to get better directions? Expect delays or even cancellations. If we were psychic enough to just know where to find you we'd be in Vegas not delivering food for $2/trip plus tips.

Doordash pays the driver $2.00 for the order, no matter how far it is from the store.  The rest comes from tips.  Most people don't tip enough, not really thinking about the app paying drivers so little.  Drivers need to make $2 per mile to cover expenses and make minimum wage.  Around here the average trip is 5 miles, but the driver is usually 2 miles from the store, and have to drive back after the delivers so the total for the trip is really 12 miles.  You would have to tip $20 to actually pay the driver enough for the order.  It's never enough, and I can't pay all of my bills driving 60 hours per week. It's a real trap for the driver.  If you don't accept 70% of the orders offered to you for you last 100 orders of the month, you will not be able to get on the schedule or work when you want the following month.  Hours are cut to about 10 hours per week without the Top Dasher status, which is 70% acceptance rate.  So, you are forced to accept low paying orders that don't pay enough for fuel and tires, just for the opportunity to work for nothing the following month.

We don't have "Grub Hub" here in Germany, instead we have "Lieferando". Interestingly with the exact same logo.
I am not going to lie, I am one of those who started using delivery apps, namely Uber Eats, after the pandemic started. Now, I would like to say that I am far from one of those horror stories you might hear about, but go ahead and say that this explanation of mine is nothing more than an excuse - that is certainly fair.  To start, I had emigrated from the US literally days before the country I went to first closed their borders before the first wave; I had no way of knowing that this would be the case. Before this, I lived in a semi-rural part of Texas, a place where delivery apps - or just delivery outside of mail or packages - simply do not work. When I emigrated, I ended up in a comparatively more urban place, where these apps are more likely to work.  As for where I emigrated to, it really makes the US look like a third-world sweatshop country (not that it ever looked like anything but such, especially not since the Reagan administration - again, used to live in semi-rural Texas). It may still be far from perfect, but there actually are worker protections here, even for gig workers. Are gig workers still exploited? Yes, they are, and that sucks. Is it as bad as in the US? No, and that does not excuse what exploitation there is. Even so, along with those protections, there are actual social services - i.e. low-cost high-quality healthcare, expanding free and/or municipal broadband, well-paved roads, extensive public transportation, etc. - so the burdens are not as bad for the workers (again, still harder than most, and that needs to be corrected). When you have _any_ actual protection as a worker by a government, you'd be amazed just how much f^^^ing better everything ends up looking and being.  As for myself, I have several points that I adhere to. Granted, since I moved, I have found myself in the unexpected position of being able to do this, which can be considered a luxury, but the fact that being in a position to be able to care for anyone's well-being other than your own is a luxury is f^^^ing bullsh^t, but I digress. I am simply beyond fed up that everything is built around, "Get yours and yours alone, and f^^^ whoever helped you get it."  Anyway, the first thing I do is check if the restaurant in question has their own delivery service. This does limit it to just the chains (and not just the international ones), but anything that goes to fully employed workers is preferred.  The second thing I do is verify that any restaurant listed actually does operate with the app(s). This is arguably the most difficult, given that the best way to do that is to go to the restaurant in question, because thankfully, if they do indeed operate with the app(s) in question, they show it with decently sized signage spelling out "Delivered by [insert app here]." As mentioned, it can be quite difficult to go to the place yourself, especially if you do not have your own car, but with a good public transportation network, as well as actual free time for anything, it is more than possible.  Third, though this is hardly exclusive to delivery, I try to keep my orders simple. Not only does it make it easier for the restaurant in question, it also means less the delivery has to go through. Restaurants and just workers in general go through enough crap as it is with their work, so the least I can do is not add anything beyond what is unavoidable.  Fourth, I am _very_ selective about when I order, particularly when it comes to weather. I know I would absolutely hate to deliever in bad weather, so I am not going to force someone else to do it for me. Yeah, I know, having empathy for some stranger paints a target on my @$$ for a conservative to aim their "symbol of freedom" at, but thankfully, the country I live in now does not have guns f^^^ing everywhere, so I am safe on that front.  Fifth, I do not use the tip feature of the app(s), and instead, I tip the person directly. Sure, it means keeping cash on hand, but it ensures that 100% of the tip goes to them. Yes, there have been a few times where I had to explain that I am from the US and therefore do not trust the app(s) to actually give the tip to them, but they have yet to refuse my action.  Sixth, and this one ties back to the fifth point, if they do end up delivering in bad weather, guess what: they get an even bigger tip. Again, if I do not want to deliver in bad weather, they should not have to for me, but if bad weather ends up striking after the order is placed (where I live, weather predictions are not that reliable, so it can happen, even after regular checks before ordering), they deserve a better payout for having to go through with it.  Is this all a luxury for me? Yes. Would I be able to any of this if I were back in the US? Absolutely not, and it is not for a lack of wanting to at all. Do I trust any of these apps to look out for people? No, abso-f^^^ing-lutely f^^^ing no, they would rather kick off WW3 than give any worker even the tiniest measure of protection or support. Am I part of the problem for using any of these apps? Yeah, I am, and even if I am far from the worst problem, I am still part of it. Am I doing what I can to try to ease, if not end, this problem? Yes. Is it easy to do? F^^^ no, and that is why it needs to be done, and the more people who are like me, even if they do not take the same approach or to the same extent that I do, the better.
